question: A.001 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which of the following is the largest effect on the reactivity worth of a control rod?

answers.answer: a. Overall reactor power
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Nuclear Reactor  Theory, LaMarsh

answers.answer: b. Drop time of the control rod
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Nuclear Reactor  Theory, LaMarsh

answers.answer: c. Axial and radial flux shape
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Nuclear Reactor  Theory, LaMarsh

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutron fraction value
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Nuclear Reactor  Theory, LaMarsh

question: A.002 [1.0 point] (2.0) Which ONE of the following describes the difference between a moderator and reflector?

answers.answer: a. A reflector increases the neutron production factor and a moderator increases the fast fission factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 1, Section 1.51 & 1.52

answers.answer: b. A reflector decreases the thermal utilization factor and a moderator increases the fast fission factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 1, Section 1.51 & 1.52

answers.answer: c. A reflector decreases the neutron production factor and a moderator decreases the fast non-leakage factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 1, Section 1.51 & 1.52

answers.answer: d. A reflector increases the fast non-leakage factor and a moderator increases the thermal utilization factor
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 1, Section 1.51 & 1.52

question: A.003 [1.0 point] (3.0) The delayed neutron fraction changes over core life primarily due to the:

answers.answer: a. buildup of Pu241 which increases the delayed neutron fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.170, Chapter 2, Table 2.10.

answers.answer: b. buildup of Pu239 which decreases the delayed neutron fraction
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.170, Chapter 2, Table 2.10.

answers.answer: c. depletion of U235 which decreases the delayed neutron fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.170, Chapter 2, Table 2.10.

answers.answer: d. depletion of U238 which increases the delayed neutron fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonke, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.170, Chapter 2, Table 2.10.

question: A.004 [1.0 point] (4.0) Select the answer that describes the inherent safety feature provided by the temperature coefficient of reactivity.

answers.answer: b. Its negative value causes reactivity to decrease as moderator temperature increases
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Basic Reactor Theory

answers.answer: c. Its positive value causes reactivity to increase as moderator temperature increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Basic Reactor Theory

answers.answer: d. Its positive value causes reactivity to decrease as moderator temperature increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Basic Reactor Theory

question: A.006 [1.0 point] (6.0) Which one of the following is the correct reason that delayed neutrons allow human control of the reactor?

answers.answer: a. Fewer prompt neutrons are produced than delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC Question

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons increase the mean neutron lifetime
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Standard NRC Question

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons take longer to thermalize than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC Question

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC Question

answers.answer: b. The most likely energy at which a charged particle will be captured
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 55

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 55

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 55

answers.answer: a. recoils with the same kinetic energy it had prior to the collision
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 64.

answers.answer: b. recoils with a lower kinetic energy, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 64.

answers.answer: c. is absorbed by the nucleus, with the nucleus emitting a beta ray
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 64.

answers.answer: d. recoils with a higher kinetic energy, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 64.

question: A.016 [1.0 point] (16.0) A step insertion of positive reactivity to a critical reactor causes a rapid increase in the neutron population known as a prompt jump. Which ONE of the following explains the cause of this occurrence?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 340.

answers.answer: b. shift in the prompt neutron lifetime on up-power maneuvers
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 340.

answers.answer: c. rapid negative reactivity insertion due to the fuel temperature coefficient (Doppler) feedback
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 340.

answers.answer: d. magnitude of the reactivity insertion exceeding the value of the average effective delayed neutron fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 3rd Edition, page 340.

question: A.018 [1.0 point] (18.0) The AGN-201 is designed to produce a fission rate within the thermal fuse that is approximately twice the average of the core. Which ONE of the following describes how this higher reaction rate is accomplished?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Safety Analysis Report, dated January 2003, pg. 104.

answers.answer: b. The polystyrene media used in the thermal fuse is a better moderator, raising the thermal flux in the fuse area
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Safety Analysis Report, dated January 2003, pg. 104.

answers.answer: c. The fuel density used in the thermal fuse is twice that of the balance of the core resulting in a higher fission rate in the fuse area
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Safety Analysis Report, dated January 2003, pg. 104.

answers.answer: d. The fuel enrichment used in the thermal fuse is twice that of the balance of the core resulting in a higher fission rate in the fuse area
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Safety Analysis Report, dated January 2003, pg. 104.
